Package main

Class Tokenizer

java.lang.Object
main.Tokenizer
public class Tokenizer extends Object
This class provides functionality to break down robbie script files into a stream of keywords and key characters and separates them into individual tokens as an in-between step for interpreting instructions.

This uses a blind queue system for interacting with tokens in the file, with *peek*, *eat*, and *next* commands to interact with the token at the head of the queue.

To clarify, only a single token can be accessed from the file at a time, and this class tokenizes keywords one token at a time as they are called from the "queue".

Author:
Jared Schimpf

  • Method Details

    • eat

      public void eat(String str) throws Exception
      Removes the current token from the queue and checks it against an expected string

      Like guessing the top card of a deck before drawing it, losing the game if you were wrong.

      Parameters:
      str - the expected string, this value is compared with the token returned from the queue
      Throws:
      Exception - if the token doesn't match the expected string

    • peek

      public String peek() throws Exception
      Returns the value of the current token from the head of the queue without consuming it.

      Like looking at the top card of a deck without drawing it, or more accurately: drawing it and putting it back.

      Returns:
      The value of the current token string
      Throws:
      Exception - if the current token is empty or EOF is reached

    • next

      public String next() throws Exception
      Returns the current token string from the head of the queue, consuming it.

      Like drawing a card, once you can see it, its no longer in your deck (the queue)

      Returns:
      the current token string
      Throws:
      Exception - if the token is empty, meaning the EOF has been reached

    • nextToken

      private String nextToken() throws Exception
      Internal method that checks the characters following the current file pointer for a valid token and returns it. This partially avoids whitespace. Any whitespace before a token starts is skipped over, but whitespace is used to denote the end of a token. This method also filters out comments. comments follow the same syntax as java comments, and are described in the EBNF.

      A valid token is any string of alphanumeric characters, or the following: ';', '{', '}','!', '(', ')', ',',

      or a string: which is any valid string of characters, including escape characters, delimited by quotes. More details on the nextString and evalEsc methods.

      Returns:
      the next token string found in the file
      Throws:
      Exception - dependent on helper methods, see evalEsc and nextString for more info.

    • nextString

      private String nextString() throws Exception
      Internal method that handles string tokens when an '"' is found by the NextToken method. This requires different logic then capturing a token. A string can contain characters that are invalid in a normal token, or which otherwise denote the end of a token. This method also must check for escape characters within a string, which is handled by the evalEsc helper method.
      Returns:
      The body of the string as a token, without the surrounding quotes
      Throws:
      Exception - if EOL or EOF is reached, or if an unrecognized escaped character is given

    • evalEsc

      private char evalEsc(StringBuilder stringBuilder) throws Exception
      Internal helper method for nextString that interprets the \n, \t, \b, \r, \f, \\, \", and \' escaped characters
      Parameters:
      stringBuilder - passed in stringbuilder instance used by the nextString method to build the token. Required to append interpreted escape character to the string token.
      Returns:
      the character following the escaped character
      Throws:
      Exception - if the escaped character is unrecognized

    • grabKeyword

      private String grabKeyword() throws IOException
      Internal helper method that grabs a valid keyword token (any string of alphanumeric characters)
      Returns:
      the next valid keyword token
      Throws:
      IOException - if an I/O error occurs with getFilePointer

    • isComment

      private boolean isComment() throws IOException
      Internal helper method used to check if a token starting with '/' is a comment, in which case it is ignored and skipped over by the tokenizer
      Returns:
      Boolean value: True if comment, otherwise False
      Throws:
      IOException - if an I/O error occurs with getFilePointer

    • peekChar

      private char peekChar() throws IOException
      Internal helper method similar to peek, looks at the next character without moving past it.
      Returns:
      the next char
      Throws:
      IOException - if an I/O error occurs with getFilePointer

    • nextChar

      private char nextChar() throws IOException
      Internal helper method similar to next, returns the next char in the file, then moves past it.
      Returns:
      the next char
      Throws:
      IOException - if an I/O error occurs with file.Read
